item.title: Alexander Muir Memorial Gardens
item.description: These gardens are named after the famed composer Alexander Muir. The multi-level gardens act as a gateway into the peaceful ravine system that features walking trails which are open year-round.

item.title: Ashbridges Bay Park
item.description: Ashbridge's Bay waterfront park features expansive beaches, a marina, fishing areas and the Woodbine Beach boardwalk.

item.title: Bluffers Park (Scarborough Bluffs)
item.description: Bluffer's Park provides access for boaters and bathers to the waterfront along the base of the dramatic and geologically significant Scarborough Bluffs.

item.title: Centennial Park
item.description: One of Canada's largest urban parks, Centennial Park offers a wide range of recreational activities and facilities including a glass conservatory greenhouse with tropical plants.

item.title: Glen Rouge Campground
item.description: Glen Rouge is Toronto's only campground, providing seasonal full-service camping in a natural environment surrounded by forests and meadows that include kilometres of nature trails.

item.title: High Park
item.description: One of Toronto's largest natural ravine parks, High Park contains natural woodlands and wetlands, habitat for animals and historic cultural sites. Easily accessible by public transit, High Park offers year-round attractions and amenities.

item.title: Humber Arboretum
item.description: Situated in a natural setting in the West Humber River Valley, the Arboretum offers trails and boardwalks through acclaimed gardens, forests, meadows and wetlands.

item.title: Kew Gardens Park
item.description: Surrounded by mature oak trees, Kew Gardens Park is one of Toronto's most popular picnic grounds. Kew Gardens provides access to an extensive boardwalk along the lakeshore.

item.title: Riverdale Park East
item.description: Part of Riverdale Park, with grass fields that have been turned into a forested slope and a small wetland.

item.title: Riverdale Park West
item.description: Part of Riverdale Park which is a large park spanning the Lower Don River in Toronto.

item.title: Rouge Park
item.description: Rouge Park is over 40 km2, protecting two National Historic Sites and a variety of ecosystems joining the post-glacial Oak Ridges Moraine, roughly 50 km north of Toronto, and the City's biggest wetland, where the Rouge River empties into Lake Ontario.

item.title: Toronto Music Garden
item.description: Is a part of the City's harbourfront parkland system and can be appreciated on many levels with its spirit of music, dance and artistic delight. The garden design interprets in nature Bach's First Suite for Unaccompanied Cello.

item.title: Sugar Beach Park
item.description: Sugar Beach is a whimsical new park that transformed a surface parking lot in a former industrial area into Toronto's second urban beach at the waters edge.

item.title: HTO Park
item.description: The urban beach is the focal point of HTO Park. It faces the inner harbour with Toronto islands in the distance.

item.title: Village of Yorkville Park
item.description: Originally a parking lot space converted into a neighbourhood park, this park was designed with elements taken from Yorkville's history and Canada's diverse geographical landscape. Each landscape represents a distinct garden feature including a grove, herb garden and marsh.

item.title: Toronto Island Park
item.description: A waterfront picnic park made up of several islands with tourist features such as the Gibraltar Point Lighthouse, Franklin Children's Garden and Centreville Amusement Park.

item.title: Humber Bay Park ( Humber Bay Butterfly Habitat)
item.description: Is a waterfront park located in Etobicoke that consists of two landspits situated at the mouth of Mimico Creek. The Humber Bay Butterfly Habitat is an ecological restoration project that provides critical habitat for a variety of native butterfly species.
